Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: One-step Production of Lactic Acid from Lignocellulosic Biomass by Recombinant Cellulolytic Bacillus subtilis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project will further develop new proprietary cellulolytic Bacillus subtilis strains that can produce high-titer, optically- pure L-lactate in high yields from pretreated lignocellulosic biomass through consolidated bioprocessing (CBP) technology. Lactate, or equivalently, lactic acid, is the precursor of the biodegradable plastic polylactic acid (PLA). The following Phase I goals were achieved: (i) the creation of a cellulolytic B. subtilis strain with an enhanced cellulolytic ability, (ii) the demonstration of lactate production from pretreated biomass without the use of cellulases, and (iii) the secretion of large-size heterologous proteins in B. subtilis. This Phase II project will further engineer strains with enhanced cellulolytic ability, and will seek to increase product yield, productivity (i.e., its space time yield), titer, and purity using systems biology and synthetic biology tools. At completion of this project, the goal is to have industrially-ready CBP strains that can hydrolyze pretreated lignocellulosic biomass efficiently, with product yields of >90% based on mixed biomass sugars and >95% based on glucose, a titer of ~150 g/L, and a productivity of ~1 g/L/h. Such Bacillus strains will be ready for large-scale fermentation as a continuing commercialization phase.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is the production of a key building-block chemical from biomass. New proprietary recombinant cellulolytic B. subtilis strainsdeveloped in this project will provide an ultra-low-cost platform for producing L-lactate from the non-food biomass, with many advantages over other developing CBP microorganisms. Large-scale production of L-lactate from pretreated lignocellulosic biomass will enable the development of other CBP microorganisms that could produce PLA, biochemicals (e.g., succinate) and advanced drop-in biofuels (e.g., isobutanol, jet fuel) in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This SBIR Phase II project was planned to further develop new proprietary cellulolytic Bacillus subtilis strains that can produce high-titer, optically-pure L-lactate in high yields from pretreated lignocellulosic biomass through consolidated bioprocessing (CBP) technology. In this Phase II project, we planned to further engineer strains with enhanced cellulolytic ability, and to increase product yield, productivity, titer, and purity using systems biology and synthetic biology tools.

Through the development and engineering of new components for a novel cellulolytic system, cell surface displayed cellulosomes were successfully assembled in B. subtilis. It was shown that the strains with surface displayed cellulosomes exhibited higher performance towards the hydrolysis of crystalline cellulose. D-xylose utilization is a key issue for lignocellulosic biomass fermentation, and a major problem in this process is carbon catabolite repression (CCR). We successfully achieved the simultaneous co-fermentation of C5 and C6 sugars using genetically modified B. subtilis strains. Much higher titer and yield were achieved (increased almost 2-fold for the best mutant) for lactate fermentation with these mutant strains.

The properties of a promising cellulase candidate CbCelA was investigated. The newly engineered enzyme BsCel5-CbCelA showed strong capability toward the hydrolysis of COSLIF-pretreated biomass, making it a good candidate to be incorporated into the artificial cellulosome. The cell surface displayed cellulosomes were successfully assembled in B. subtilis with a six-cohensin scaffoldin backbone. It was showed that the strains with surface displayed cellulosomes exhibited higher performance towards the hydrolysis of COSLIF-pretreated biomass.

Based on the outcome of Free-to-Operate (FTO) search, the engineering of the prototype strain was initiated and the pre-prototype strain was successfully engineered. The chiral purity of lactate produced by B. subtilis was determined to be 99.5%, which is high enough for commercial production. A small scale fermenter with automatically controlled systems was successfully established and the lactate fermentation with high concentration of substrate loading was performed. The productivity of lactate was more than 1.0 g/L/h and the titer exceeded 100 g/L.

We have successfully engineered a pre-prototype strain and improved its growth tolerance to higher temperature. We have also assembled a cellulosome system on the surface of the pre-prototype strain, with a hydrolysis rate of 58% for COSLIF-treated biomass, an improvement of at least 10% compared to the cellulosome system assembled in the previous cellulolytic strain, or the free cellulase system in the previous cellulolytic strain. It is important for the cellulolytic Bacillus to be able to simultaneously co-ferment C5 and C6 sugars without a decrease in the sugar utilization and growth rates. Through the rational design and introduction of double mutations in the global regulator protein, we successfully recovered the sugar utilization and growth rates of the recombinant B. subtilis strain. The inoculation size for the seed culture was investigated and the best inoculation size and the concentration for yeast extract were confirmed.

The major remaining problem in this project was to construct the marker-free prototype cellulolytic B. subtilis strain. Although the pre-prototype strain was successfully constructed, we encountered extreme difficulty incorporating all the key features we developed into one strain to get the prototype strain. One possible reason might be that so many large heterologous enzymes cause a big burden for cell metabolism.
